conclusion: The p-V image of the change process of an ideal gas of a certain mass from state A to state B and then to state C is shown in Figure 7. The temperature of the gas in state A is known to be 27 °C.

The image depicts a p-V diagram for an ideal gas undergoing a process from state A to state B and then to state C. The vertical axis represents pressure (p) in units of 10^5 Pa, while the horizontal axis represents volume (V) in units of 10^-3 m^3. The diagram shows a horizontal line from A to B, indicating constant pressure, and a vertical line from B to C, indicating constant volume.

premise: The diagram shows two segments of the process: AB and BC. From A to B, the pressure remains constant at 3 × 10^5 Pa, while the volume changes from 2 × 10^-3 m^3 to 3 × 10^-3 m^3.

For a constant pressure process, the work done by the gas is given by \(W = p \times \Delta V\). Here, \(p = 3 \times 10^5 \, \text{Pa}\) and \(\Delta V = 3 \times 10^-3 \, \text{m}^3 - 2 \times 10^-3 \, \text{m}^3 = 10^-3 \, \text{m}^3\).
The line BC is vertical, indicating a constant volume process.
conclusion: Identify Work for BC: No work is done during this segment.

premise: The work done externally by the gas from B to C is equal to the work done internally from A to B, which is 300 J.
